messageBody:
I agree with Joe and Cedric here, don't really see why you want to
test it but some important infomration might me missing.

Whaat I do see is an oportunity to talk about intercept in rMock that
can be used to test this kind of thing (but just because you can
doesn't mean you should, hmm maybe that includes talking about
features aswell in the wrong context aswell...).


public class MyClassUnderTest {
public void myRecursiveMethod(int times) {
if ( times > 0) {
myRecursiveMethod(--times);
}
}
}




public class RecursicveTest extends RMockTestCase {
private MyClassUnderTest cut;
public void setUp() {
cut = (MyClassUnderTest)intercept(MyClassUnderTest.class,
"classUnderTest");
}

public void testRecurse() {
cut.myRecursiveMethod(4);
modify().multiplicity(expect.exactly(4)).args(is.gt(-1)).forward();
// The modification ensures that the method is called no more
than and no less than
// 4 times. As long as times is greater than -1 it is ok and
when a method call with these parameters is intercepted the call is
forwarded to the underlying implementation of the method.

startVerification();
// lets start verifying what we setUp

cut.myRecursiveMethod(4);
}

}

I have never written a test like this and I don't think I will in the
future either, this is purely for fun.

What I have done though is to use itercept to extend AbstractClasses
to verify the abstract classes contracts. What I have used it even
more for is to verify that streams, readers, writers that I pass to
classes I test are closed (or not closed) as expected (or similar
situations).

Hope it was at least almost as fun reading the example as it was for
me writing it. I have not run the test though so I don't know if it
fails, would be pretty embarassing if it looped more/fewer times than
I expected :P

Regards
Joakim Ohlrogge






amine achergui wrote:

> Is there any test pattern to test a recursive method ( in my case,
> the method's body calls collaborators thus in the test method i use mocks).
> Is there any pattern or recipe to solve this?

So you have a method that wants to invoke itself, and you'd like to mock
the call to itself.

In this case, ignore the method being repetitively recursive, because by
putting a mock in there, you're ensuring that the method will only call
itself one. (The mock won't invoke itself any more than that.)

As for a method invoking itself, there's no direct way to mock the
invocation. Some basic reasoning should make that clear: if the method
is mocked, then it wouldn't invoke itself. :)

I have thought about this in the abstract before, and don't have an
answer, except to point out that I've never wanted to do this. There
must be a reason for that, and I hope it's a good one. :)

Can you tell us what this method does? Perhaps that will shed some light
on what to do.
